name: Amoud Foundation
mission: Founded in 1998, the Amoud Foundation impacts the local and global communities by helping people help themselves through sustainable humanitarian projects while maintaining trusting relationships. Amoud is an international humanitarian organization that today serves the people in the Horn of Africa. Amoud also does work on the home-front including helping with the 2006 Hurricane Relief and 2015 Garland Tornado recovery.
theoryOfChange: Amoud Foundation states it helps people help themselves through sustainable humanitarian projects while maintaining trusting relationships, and relieves suffering by establishing emergency relief and development programs.
zakatClaimEvidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://www.amoudfoundation.org/zakat (Source: https://www.amoudfoundation.org/zakat)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Good donor alignment with manageable risk. Evidence quality is solid but still evolving in places.

components.evidence: Explicit zakat program (+4); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Asnaf: fuqara (+5); Operates in Muslim-majority regions (+3); Strong humanitarian service (+4)

components.improvement_suggestion: Expand services to underserved populations or geographies with limited nonprofit coverage.

components.improvement_suggestion: If reserves are above policy target, document why and publish triggers for planned deployment.

score_details.score_summary: AMOUD FOUNDATION shows exceptional impact and strong alignment, with zakat compliance.

all_citations.claim: Amoud Foundation has a Charity Navigator score of 88.5/100 and supports 15 orphan centers.
The charity is zakat-eligible and follows specific policies for asnaf categories.
The organization provides various donation options and giving methods for supporters.
Amoud Foundation offers volunteer opportunities and engagement pathways for the community.
The foundation reported total revenue of $9,535,194 and a program expense ratio of 89.3%.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: Amoud Foundation earns a high overall rating due to its excellent financial health, efficient use of donor funds, and direct service model that prioritizes vulnerable populations.
areas_for_improvement: Enhancing data confidence through increased third-party reporting
Expanding public documentation of long-term impact metrics for educational programs

dimension_explanations.alignment: The foundation shows strong alignment with Muslim donor priorities through its zakat-eligible status and focus on high-urgency religious and cultural causes [2]. It offers multiple engagement pathways, including volunteer opportunities and structured giving methods for various asnaf categories [3][4].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization demonstrates high impact by maintaining a program expense ratio of 89.3% and a total revenue of $9,535,194, which supports direct services for orphans and healthcare initiatives [1][5]. Its financial stability is further evidenced by 12.7 months of working capital and a Charity Navigator score of 88.5/100 [1].

baseline_narrative.headline: Amoud Foundation provides critical humanitarian relief and educational support to vulnerable orphans and students with disabilities.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 89.3%, ensuring the vast majority of funds reach beneficiaries
Exceptional fundraising efficiency with a cost of $0.00 per $1 raised
Strong liquidity with 12.7 months of working capital available
baseline_narrative.summary: Amoud Foundation is a non-profit organization dedicated to assisting 15 orphan centers and two specialized schools for deaf and blind students [1]. The foundation maintains a high level of financial transparency and is recognized as zakat-eligible, allowing donors to fulfill religious obligations through various humanitarian programs [2].

areas_for_improvement.context: While financial health is strong, the <cite id="17">Accountability beacon score of 88</cite> suggests room for improvement in public governance disclosures.
The organization's impact is highly concentrated in <cite id="2">Somalia and Somaliland</cite>, which presents localized risk.

bbb_assessment.summary: BBB assessment data is not currently available for this organization.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The foundation mitigates this through long-standing local partnerships and a high liquidity reserve.
risk_factors: <cite id="2">Concentration of operations in a single conflict-prone region</cite>
case_against.summary: Limited concerns primarily involve <cite id="17">transparency gaps in accountability metrics</cite> and high geographic concentration.

confidence.data_freshness: Most data from 2023 Form 990 and 2024 Charity Navigator updates
confidence.notes: Strong financial data and leadership scores provide high confidence in operational efficiency.

alignment.explanation: Strong fit for Muslim donors with <cite id="8">verified zakat eligibility</cite> and focus on <cite id="9">orphans and vulnerable students</cite> in Muslim-majority regions.
alignment.improvement: The charity could improve alignment by <cite id="2">expanding services to other underserved geographies</cite> with limited nonprofit coverage.

credibility.explanation: Donors can trust this charity due to its <cite id="1">28-year track record</cite> and its <cite id="14">perfect score in Leadership & Adaptability</cite> from Charity Navigator.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility further, the charity could improve its <cite id="17">accountability score</cite> by publishing more detailed board meeting minutes and independent audits.

impact.explanation: Operations show a <cite id="5">89.3% program expense ratio</cite> with <cite id="12">12.7 months of working capital</cite>, indicating high efficiency and sustainability.
impact.improvement: If reserves remain significantly <cite id="12">above 12 months</cite>, the charity should document specific plans for deploying these funds to expand services.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade B - Verified outcomes and documented Theory of Change

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Direct implementation of programs rather than grantmaking

rich_narrative.headline: Amoud Foundation provides critical humanitarian relief and educational support to vulnerable orphans and students with disabilities.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who prioritize extreme financial efficiency and want to support orphan care and disability education in the Horn of Africa through a zakat-eligible vehicle.
donor_motivations: Want to ensure nearly 100% of their donation reaches the field
Care about specialized education for deaf and blind students
Seek to fulfill zakat obligations through a long-standing, stable institution
Value direct service delivery over advocacy
giving_considerations: The organization has very high reserves, meaning your gift contributes to long-term stability
Operations are concentrated in Somalia, a region with high humanitarian need but significant political risk
Fundraising costs are virtually non-existent, maximizing the impact of every dollar
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking a broad global footprint or those who prefer organizations with a heavy focus on US-based domestic programs.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade B reflects verified outcomes and a <cite id="16">documented theory of change</cite>, though large-scale independent RCTs are not present.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: The foundation uses a direct-service model to provide education and basic needs to orphans, aiming to break the cycle of poverty through specialized support.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that the $11.29 spent per beneficiary actually results in improved life outcomes for the students and orphans served.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: Despite strong reserves, the scale of humanitarian need in Somalia allows for significant absorption of new capital for program expansion.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by a <cite id="5">89.3% program ratio</cite>, which is significantly higher than the <cite id="6">peer median of 89.8%</cite>.

strengths.detail: The foundation maintains a <cite id="5">89.3% program expense ratio</cite> and an <cite id="11">exceptional fundraising efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised</cite>.
Amoud Foundation holds <cite id="12">12.7 months of working capital</cite> in working capital, ensuring long-term stability.
The organization delivers services at a cost of approximately <cite id="13">$11.29 per beneficiary</cite>, which is considered exceptional for humanitarian aid.

strengths_deep_dive: Amoud Foundation's operational model is characterized by its direct service delivery, which minimizes intermediary costs. Their <cite id="1">overall score of 88.88.5/100 from Charity Navigator</cite> is bolstered by a <cite id="14">perfect 100/100 Leadership score</cite>. This leadership has successfully scaled the organization's reach while maintaining a <cite id="15">3-year revenue growth rate of 18.6%</cite>. Furthermore, the foundation's commitment to transparency is evidenced by its <cite id="16">documented theory of change</cite>, which provides a clear roadmap for how their interventions in education and orphan care lead to long-term community resilience.
rich_narrative.summary: Founded in <cite id="1">1998</cite>, Amoud Foundation is a specialized humanitarian organization focused on providing critical relief and educational support to vulnerable populations in <cite id="2">Somaliland and Somalia</cite>. The organization manages a robust portfolio of programs including <cite id="3">15 orphan centers and two specialized schools</cite> for deaf and blind students. Financially, the foundation operates with exceptional efficiency, reporting <cite id="4">$9,535,194 in total revenue</cite> for the 2023 tax year. A hallmark of their operational model is the <cite id="5">89.3% program expense ratio</cite>, which significantly exceeds the <cite id="6">industry standard of 75%</cite>. This lean structure ensures that nearly every dollar donated is converted into direct services, such as <cite id="7">Water Is Life, Emergency Aid, and Health Care</cite> initiatives. The organization is deeply rooted in the Islamic philanthropic tradition, maintaining <cite id="8">verified zakat eligibility</cite> and directing funds toward the <cite id="9">fuqara, masakin, and fisabilillah</cite> categories of asnaf. With a <cite id="10">3-year revenue CAGR of 18.6%</cite>, Amoud Foundation has demonstrated consistent growth and an increasing capacity to address the complex humanitarian needs of the Horn of Africa.
